comments:
CDT 2.0.2 (2004101437)

A C++ managed project is not usable in any language other than English after 
reopening Eclipse (create C++ managed project, close Eclipse, reopen 
Eclipse).   

Steps to reproduce:
1) Download Eclipse 3.0.1, CDT 2.0.2 and their respectable NL fragments.
2) Launch Eclipse (in French say):  eclipse -nl FR
3) Create a Managed Build Project
    You will see in the C/C++ Projects View that the project is created.  
Under the project, the "Inclut" directory will show up.

4) Close Eclipse
5) launch (eclipse -nl FR with the same workspace) 

The project will then be unusable.  The cause of the defect is at the bottom 
of this bug.

Several problems occured:
-The "Inclut" directory is gone.  Therefore the index will not be correct. 
Consequently Search will not work.
-The project cannot be built
-The "C/C++ Compiler" and "Error Parser" project properties can not be viewed. 
2 exceptions occured when trying to view them:

These problems are caused by having non-ASCII characters in the .cdtbuild 
file.
*** Bug 76329 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

It looks like the problem is in the save method. I created a UTF-8 encoded XML 
transform alright. The problem is that when I extracted the individual bytes to 
the ByteArrayInputStream that I was feeding into the file constructor, I was 
not specifying that they have to be treated as UTF-8 bytes. I made a couple of 
basic changes to make doubly sure that everything is encoded just right and I 
can check them into the head and 2.0.X streams as soon as I do some regression 
testing.

Created an attachment (id=15329)
Patched JAR file

Replace the currunet jar file in the Managed Build core plugin with this one

The fix was basic and involved one class only, 
org.eclipse.cdt.managedbuilder.core.ManagedBuildManager. The key change is in 
the call to set contents of the file. It changed from:

projectFile.setContents(new ByteArrayInputStream(utfString.getBytes()), ...)

to:
projectFile.setContents(new ByteArrayInputStream(utfString.getBytes
("UTF8")), ...)
